pullRequest.body:
Add a GitHub action triggered on the `!bench` comments.

Reports a summary of the changes by at least 10^9 instructions. [This PR](https://github.com/bryangingechen/mathlib4/pull/12#issuecomment-2328756897) contains various examples of reports generated by this script.

[Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/bench.20summaries)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e27dfa7992](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16488/commits/e27dfa799235981ab3f7c342012aa4abe524fd35)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Bench`
`+ addBenchSummaryComment`
`+ benchOutput`
`+ formatDiff`
`+ formatFile`
`+ formatPercent`
`+ intDecs`
`+ summary`
`+ toCollapsibleTable`
`+ toTable`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11472046806/job/31923970592)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11472046806/job/31923970259)

The main thing was to agree if these changes are acceptable to you as well. I've pushed a tiny tweak, and am happy with this PR. (There are several directions for extending it, but none of these need to happen in this PR.) Thanks for writing it!
maintainer merge

Thanks for writing this and slowly automating Michael Stoll's manual comments! This looks very useful!

I took a look up to line 100 of `bench_summary`. Here's my usual bunch of persnickety comments.
Michael, thank you for the review: I implemented all your comments!

I randomly stumbled across this PR. I still find it useful, so left a few tweaks and a review. Enjoy! I pushed a commit with some changes directly. Please revert any you disagree with (or let's discuss)!
In any case: the current summary is *much* better than none --- I can happily postpone many comments to a follow-up!

I also wondered if the output can be clarified slightly, by printing the range of instructions for each collapsible table. WDYT?

Michael, thank you so much for reviewing this further!

You labelled the PR as awaiting-author, but... what is left for me to do?  :smile:

The main thing was to agree if these changes are acceptable to you as well. I've pushed a tiny tweak, and am happy with this PR. (There are several directions for extending it, but none of these need to happen in this PR.) Thanks for writing it!
maintainer merge
If I remember #16241 correctly, you should remove the `!= null` part.
Removed `!= null`.

WDYT?
```suggestion
    name: Post summary of benchmarking results
Looks good, thanks!

"~" is (AFAIK) a UNIX-ism that not everybody might understand. Is this supposed to be an absolute "path" ("My.Deep-Directories.Nesting.Mathlib.Path.To.File") or more like "Mathlib.Path.To.File"? If the latter, I would just remove the tilde.

This is just the format in which the speedcenter returns paths: `Mathlib.X...` is returned as `~Mathlib.X...`, while `build` and `lint` are returned without the `~`.

I later strip that off with `.dropWhile (!Â·.isAlpha)`.

```suggestion
It writes the number as `x.y * 10 ^ exp`, where `y` has `prec` digits and returns

```suggestion
/-- Convert a `Float` into a formatted string of the form `Â±z.w%`. -/
Small detail: you don't need the parens anymore, right?
If you want, you could inline `sgnf`. (I don't know Lean's coercion rules well: can you multiply sgn and reldiff directly? If so, you could perhaps even remove it.)
Inlining works and I did it. Heterogeneous multiplication does not, though.
Great idea to add a test!
Would you like to also test `formatDiff` (can be with the same data)?
Added a test of `formatDiff` as well.
My brain gave up trying to mentally parse the "`` `file``". I'll trust you go this right; it's for documentation only anyway.
You are right that there was a bug: the input string is enclosed in backticks for md-formatting.
"into a markdown table"?

I'm assuming this can be deleted?
```suggestion
```

Actually, line28 of the workflow 

```
          sed "s=--\(run_cmd .*\) putPR=\1 ${PR}=" scripts/bench_summary.lean |
```

uncomments this line and makes it live in CI.

Oh wow! It would be good to have a normal comment above this line explaining this.

**edit** And maybe it should be mentioned in the module docstring as well, since this is a rather nonstandard way of interacting with a lean file...

I modified the workflow, by both, adding a comment in the file, but also changing the `sed` line to a "`cat` + `printf`" pair that *adds* the extra line, rather than uncommenting the one present in the file.

One of my first thoughts was: "surely this can be rewritten as a `script`, callable via `lake exe`, right"? Right now, the answer is no (because the script uses `IO.Log`, which requires a stronger monad than just `IO`) --- but this is just for debugging, right? (You *could* sneakily use dbg_trace, I presume...?)

Put differently: the current set-up is clever, but I wonder if something more standard is possible.
I'll happily push a commit rewriting this as a script, if you think that is good.

A script would be nice, but maybe I would wait to see if there is interest in actually running this script outside of CI.  Btw, using `IO.print`/`IO.println` may be better than `dbg_trace`, assuming that they are in the right monad.

Good point. I was thinking about this mainly from a maintainance point of view: adding a script is well-understood - but this can easily be a follow-up.

Sure, `IO.println` would work (you just need an output file...).
I think "bin" is the proper statistics term here (but I am not a professional statistician).
I'm happy to go with bins!
You're sorting here to ensure "build" always comes before "lint", right?
It's been a while, but I think that this is indeed the reason!  :smile:
Just to clarify: there are no "empty" bins as the `groupBy` would never produce such, right?
Yes, there are no empty "bins", but there could be no bins at all, if the initial list is empty.  Boring, but I also do not think that it is a problem!
Indeed!
Ah, the point is to never print collapsible tables with a single entry. Perhaps saying so would be helpful.

Right, a collapsible tab with a single entry is overkill.  I wanted to have a mechanism that would allow to modify the threshold for the number of entries that get collapsed and chose 1 as initial threshold.
Sure. I've added a comment, and am happy with that :-)
This also collapses a single group with one file: this is intentional, but a comment somewhere would be good. I added one further down; feel free to rephrase/remove again.
Great, thanks!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CI): add summary of benchmarking output
